name: Rep. Jay Obernolte

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: We must also cut back on spending to lower our debt. My Finding Federal Savings Committee Resolution will identify and either eliminate or modify underperforming and nonessential federal programs to save money and streamline the bloated federal bureaucracy.

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: My Balanced Budget Constitutional Amendment will prevent further growth of the national debt by requiring the federal government to do what every American family across the country must do - make sure their spending does not exceed the amount of money they bring in every year.

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: The U.S. currently has a debt of over $28 trillion; that’s $84,850 for every American citizen. If we allow that debt to continue to rise, we'll see fewer jobs, higher prices at the grocery store, less improvements on our roads, decreased home values and higher mortgage payments.

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: My first bills introduced in the U.S. House of Representatives are a Constitutional Amendment to ensure Congress balances our nation's budget and a new bill to cut down on federal spending by eliminating wasteful programs: https://t.co/4IiRZrJPSV

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: The JUSTICE Act incentivizes trainings to reduce use of force, ends the use of choke holds, and promotes transparency by enhancing the use of body cameras. It’s time America works to support and improve our law enforcement agencies - not defund them.

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: I've cosponsored a common-sense alternative to this bill called the JUSTICE Act which implements many of the same provisions while still protecting our law enforcement personnel.

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: We are a nation based on the rule of law - defunding our police is not a viable option, and stripping them of their ability to operate is a dangerous path to go down.

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: We saw an unprecedented spike in murders in 2020, particularly in places where there were efforts to undermine our law enforcement officers or defund their agencies.

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: This bill eliminates qualified immunity which protects law enforcement personnel from frivolous lawsuits unless they violate a person’s rights or break the law. Our police need to know they can take proper & necessary actions w/o fear of being sued for simply doing their jobs.

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: THREAD: We all agree that our justice system needs common sense reforms.  Unfortunately the Justice in Policing Act we voted on in the House today would make it nearly impossible for law enforcement officers to do their jobs and keep our communities safe.

tweet_text: 4/5: Most of the funding for education included in the bill doesn't take effect for three years, while spending items like $140 million for BART take priority. This also further disadvantages rural Americans living near the poverty line and disproportionately favors large cities.

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: 3/5: Additionally, it will bring the total amount of spending to nearly $6 trillion since March 2020 - over $17,000 per American. However, nearly 1 in every 4 dollars previously allocated for COVID-19 relief already remains unspent. More on that here: https://t.co/Ll3jtBkG11

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: 2/5: This is one of the largest spending packages in the history of Congress at $1.9T, but only 9% will go towards fighting the coronavirus. The other 91% is appropriated for relief & stimulus at a rate that economists say puts our economy in serious danger of overheating.

name: Rep. Jay Obernolte
tweet_text: 1/5: I feel we are all united in the belief that Congress should respond quickly to the COVID crisis & get our country back on its feet, but unfortunately the $1.9T spending bill we voted on early this morning will have the effect of hurting the very people we are trying to help.
